`-1` for negative numbers, and `0` for `0`.

This theorem, `inner_zero_left`, states that for any scalar type `ð•œ` and any normed add commutative group `E` with an inner product space over `ð•œ`, the inner product of the zero vector and any vector `x` in `E` is always zero. This is a fundamental property of inner product spaces, essentially stating that the zero vector is orthogonal to all other vectors.

This is a fundamental property of inner product spaces, essentially stating that the zero vector is orthogonal to all other vectors.

For any nontrivially normed field `ð•œ`, normed additive commutative group `E`, normed space `E` over `ð•œ`, and topological space `H`, the function `I` from `ð•œ` to `E` defined in a Model With Corners `I` of types `ð•œ`, `E`, and `H` is uniquely differentiable on its entire range.

  [inst_2 : NormedSpace ð•œ E] {H : Type u_3} [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace H] (I : ModelWithCorners ð•œ E H),
  UniqueDiffOn ð•œ (Set.range â†‘I)

docString: For any nontrivially normed field `ð•œ`, normed additive commutative group `E`, normed space `E` over `ð•œ`, and topological space `H`, the function `I` from `ð•œ` to `E` defined in a Model With Corners `I` of types `ð•œ`, `E`, and `H` is uniquely differentiable on its entire range.

The theorem `innerDualCone_zero` states that for any type `H` that is a normed add commutative group and has an inner product space over the real numbers, the dual cone of the convex cone consisting only of the zero vector is the whole space `H`. In other words, any point `y` in space `H` satisfies the condition that the inner product of `y` and `0` is nonnegative, hence all points `y` in `H` belong to the dual cone of the zero vector.

In other words, any point `y` in space `H` satisfies the condition that the inner product of `y` and `0` is nonnegative, hence all points `y` in `H` belong to the dual cone of the zero vector.
